title: pupils six areas england free
story: :root Pupils in six areas of England to get free glasses under new government schemeAround , pupils are expected to get two pairs each of free glasses, with help of a vision co-ordinator, in Doncaster, Derby, Durham, Norwich and Breckland, and the North Yorkshire CoastIts feared there is a hidden tide of children who dont know they need spectaclesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Sep | commentsThousands of pupils in six areas of England will be given two pairs of free glasses each in a bid to fight the hidden scourge of poor eyesight. The Department for Educationtoday announces it has expanded its Glasses in Classes scheme to reach more than , pupils in at least  schools in England. It was trialled in Bradford and will now be expanded to Doncaster, Derby, Durham, Norwich and Breckland, and the North Yorkshire Coast. Children identied as needing glasses will receive one pair for home and one for school to help improve reading and writing skills. Children can already get free eye tests and vouchers for glasses but experts fear many poorer pupils do not have sight problems spotted in time. Under the scheme, pupils receive support from a vision co-ordinator, usually a teaching assistant, to attend follow-up eye examinations, get their prescription glasses and wear them regularly.  Schools do not usually get the results of vision screenings that pupils take in reception. But during the pilot, these results were shared with staff in schools so they knew which pupils and families to support. The scheme, first piloted at  primary schools in Bradford, aims to prevent disadvantaged pupils from being left behind because of poor eyesight. It will now be adapted for five disadvantaged areas in England under the DfEaposs Opportunity Areas programme - where the Government has targeted more resources at  social mobility cold spots. Speaking on National Eye Health Week, Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: As a young boy shortly after arriving in this country, I sat at the back of the classroom with poor language skills and low confidence, struggling to engage with my lessons. Back then, I could never have dreamt of the opportunities this country would give me and I am determined to help every young person overcome obstacles, just as I was supported. Too many children still struggle with the literacy skills they need to make the most of their education. Simple steps like providing free glasses to those that need them so they can clearly see words on a page, for example, can help close the literacy gap and foster a love of learning. Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders , said: This novel scheme focuses on young people whose learning is hampered by poor eyesight and whose circumstances mean they have either not been to see an optician or do not have the glasses they need. It is refreshing to see the Government reacting positively to a local initiative that has seen results in Bradford and extending it to a further five disadvantaged areas in the north of the country. It would be greatit could eventually be rolled out on a national basis to bring the same benefits to all young people. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersapos union NAHT, said: It is essential that the Government invests more in education and young people, and does so without delay. Programmes like this are encouraging but what the education sector is crying out for is a fully funded strategy for education recovery which meets the needs of all pupils in all areas of the country. Thereaposs no time to waste, particularly because the Comprehensive Spending Review will be delivered next month.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Paul WhitemanNadhim ZahawiEducationSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: second mod data breach uncovered
story: :root Second MOD data breach uncovered putting safety of Afghan interpreters at riskDozens of people who may be eligible to come to the UK were mistakenly copied into an email earlier this monthAfghans who assisted Western forces are eligible to come to the UK under a relocation scheme Image: MoD Crownvia Getty ImByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Sep | commentsA second data breach potentially risking the lives of Afghan interpreters has been uncovered at the Ministry of Defence. Dozens of people who may be eligible to come to the UK under the Afghan Relocation and Assistance Policywere mistakenly copied into an email earlier this month. Their email addresses were visible to all recipients, rather than being blind copied. Some  peopleaposs details were revealed, according to the BBC. The disastrous blunder comes after Defence Secretary Ben Wallace was forced to apologise for a separate breach that revealed the email addresses of around  Afghans. Terried interpreters have spoken of fears for their safety after the first data breach - and Tory MP Johnny Mercer has said Afghan allies are being hunted ruthlessly by the Taliban.  Mr Wallace told MPs this week that an official had been suspended for the first breach and expressed his fury at the blunder. It is an unacceptable level of service that has let down the thousands of members of the armed forces and veterans. On behalf of the Ministry of Defence, I apologise, Mr Wallace said. I offer the reassurances that the scheme will continue to operate and bring people back to the United Kingdom for however many are eligible and however long it takes. An MoD spokesperson said: We have been made aware of a data breach that occurred earlier this month by the Afghan Relocation and Assistance Policy team. This week, the Defence Secretary instigated an investigation into data handling within that team. Steps have now been taken to ensure this does not happen in the future. We apologise to those affected and extra support is being offered to them. Admiral Sir Ben Key, the commander of joint operations who led the planning and evacuation from Kabul, is leading the investigation and one person had been suspended. It also comes after documents identying Afghan workers and job applicants were abandoned in the embassy in Kabul. Mr Wallace said at the time: Clearly itaposs not good enough. news politics tories-blind-economic-hardships-families-"Kwasi Kwarteng discusses struggling energy suppliersopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Sep | commentsThe responsibility for the energy crisis rocking Britain lies firmly at the door of this Government. Today two power firms collapsed, leaving , customers facing higher bills. Other smaller providers are also expected to fail. The impact is not just being felt in domestic fuel bills. The sharp increase in energy prices is hurting business, disrupting supplies to stores and upping the cost of the weekly shop. It is no use ministers wringing their hands and blaming the global rise in wholesale prices. They were warned years ago that Britain required a more secure energy supply. Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  Other nations are weathering the storm as they invested in gas storage and ersied their sources of power. The Tories placed their faith in a broken system of market forces. We are now paying the price for their complacency. Millions of households are now set for a stark winter of soaring energy bills, higher taxes and rising inflation. The Government are blind to the economic hardship facing so many families. At least they could cancel cutting Universal Credit, which will put more people into poverty. PM all hot air Boris Johnson appealed to world leaders to join together to tackle global warming. His call comes as Britain prepares to host next month’s COP summit, where nations will be asked to commit to reducing emissions. It is crucial the meeting succeeds in its aims. Get all the latest news straight to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newslettersMr Johnson is right to champion this cause. But he does himself no favours by lecturing other states about backing developing nations when his own Government has cut its ­international aid budget. Britain is also failing to meet its own targets on cutting carbon output. The Prime Minister needs to start practising what he preaches. Pining for tree Suppliers are warning of a shortage of Christmas trees this winter. Given this Government’s record the lights will have gone out as well. news politics tories-secret-talks-raise-universal-"Universal Credit: George Eustice discusses cutsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsShamed Tory ministers have launched private talks about raising Universal Credit for .million Brits - weeks after cutting it by £. The Mirror understands there are “live discussions” inside the Department for Work and Pensionsabout changing the “taper rate” to let working families keep more money.A proposal under discussion would see the taper - which is the amount of Universal Credit withdrawn for every pound someone earns - cut from p to p. Sources say the DWP is lobbying the Treasury to improve the rate as part of Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs October  Budget. The Treasury is said to be exploring the idea.It would be the first taper change in five years, and would partially cushion the blow of the £-a-week cut - which kicks into payments between October  and November . Scroll down for an explanation of what this all means. Are you struggling on Universal Credit  E-mail webnews@mirror.  The £billion-a-year move would leave many working benefit claimants p better off, rather than the current p, for every pound they earn after tax. But sources are downbeat about whether Mr Sunak - who is demanding Whitehall cuts ahead of his Spending Review - will authorise the move. Mr Sunak has already stonewalled pleas to stop the £-a-week cut, which will save him £bn-a-year but throw hundreds of thousands of families into poverty. Evena p change in the taper is approved, it will not come close to making up for the £-a-week cut for most families. A -year-old single mum working  hours a week on minimum wage could be £. a week better offthe taper rate was cut from p to p.  But because UC is being cut by £ across the board, she would still be £. worse off than she is now. And those still covered by work allowances, or too sick to work, would not benefit at all from changes to the taper. Karl Handscomb of the Resolution Foundation think tank said: “Reducing the taper rate in Universal Credit would raise incentives for workers to earn more – and boost living standards by allowing them to keep more of their earnings. But while welcome, this is no alternative to maintaining the £ a week uplt to Universal Credit. The gains are far smaller than the £ a week cut, and would flow to better off families on UC while three million families would gain nothing at all. Virtually all households would still be signicantly worse off overall.” Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey was blasted for claiming families could work an extra two hours to make up for the £ cut. Experts said many would have to work six hours due to the taper - or nine hoursthey pay tax and national insurance. A person with knowledge of the talks told the Mirror there is now no hope of reversing the £-a-week cut. Focus is turning to the taper instead, they said, adding: “It may be that they say the cut is going ahead - but here’s a lollipop”.  A second source said cutting the taper would help push claimants towards working more hours - as Ms Coffey suggested. After job vacancies topped a million, the source said: “When the economy’s growing and there are lots of job vacancies, more money should go into the taper rate because when people start work they keep more of their money. It’s an incentive.” Every penny cut from the taper would cost £million a year once Universal Credit is fully rolled out, the IFS think tank says. Some .million out of .million claimants have a job, and could benefit from a cut in the taper. Not all would benefit as some are already spared the taper, due to having a work allowance and earnings under £ a month. UCaposs architect Iain Duncan Smith, who has demanded ministers halt the £ cut, originally wanted the taper to be p but was overruled by George Osborne.Mr Duncan Smith appeared to reveal talks about the taper were under way in a Commons debate this week. He urged Ms Coffey to use his bid to stop the cut “as justication for her negotiations with the Treasury to secure a better investment in the taper.” Labour announced last month it would cut the taper, but has not said what the new taper should be.Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Jonathan Reynolds told the Mirror: Rising food costs, tax hikes, the energy crisis and cuts to Universal Credit are a perfect storm facing working families. Itaposs not too late for the Government to change course and cancel their cut. Labour is on the side of working people, thataposs why we would maintain the uplt and reduce the taper rate to allow people to keep more of the money they earn when we replace Universal Credit. The Lords Economic Committee called last year for a cut in the taper, saying the poorest in society were being hit with a “very high effective tax rate”. The committee, led by Tory former employment minister Lord Forsyth, said: “The principle of always making work pay has been undermined by cuts.”By buying a little bit extra with the weekly shop and putting it in the donation box located in-store, customers can help Lidl meet its target of donating million meals a year to those in need. Lidl is helping to tackle hunger in Britain’s communities through its Feed it Back scheme and has teamed up with partner Neighbourly to ensure any donated food will be put to good use every day.The key items to pop in the box are: Cereal Soup Pasta Rice Tinned tomatoes or pasta sauce Lentils, beans and pulses Tinned meat Tinned vegetables Tea and coffee Tinned fruit Biscuits UHT milk Fruit juice. Find out more about Lidlaposs Feed it Back scheme here. What is the taper rate in Universal Credit  Universal Credit allows people to keep claiming eventhey get a job, because some jobs pay so badly that the wage is not enough to sustain a family. If you earn money from a job while on UC, your benefits are tapered away by a set amount depending on how much youaposve earned after tax. For every £ you earn over a set threshold, your benefits are reduced by p. That means effectively youaposre only p better off for every £ you earn after tax. The taper is designed to aposmake work payapos - to smooth people off UC as they re-enter the world of work without abandoning them completely. But critics and charities have long said the taper is just too high. It leaves too little incentive to get a job because people need - hours just to make £. The taper doesnapost apply to earnings that you make under a work allowance - £ a monthyou get housing help, and £ a monthyou donapost. However, only some claimants are eligible for a work allowance - in other words,they have responsibility for a child or limited capability for work. Even those who are eligible will tip over the work allowance and into the taperthey work just eight hours a week at minimum wage. title: uk could try join trade
story: :root UK could try to join US trade pact with Mexico and Canada as hopes of deal fadeBoris Johnson faced disappointment as US President Joe Biden downplayed the prospect of a one-on-one trade agreement in a meeting at the White HouseBoris Johnson is considering other options as hopes faded of a bespoke US trade deal Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorPippa Crerar, Political Editor, in New York:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsBoris Johnson is looking at trying to join a US trade agreement with Mexico and Canada as hopes of a bespoke deal for the UK faded.The PMaposs dreams of a post-Brexit pact with the US appeared to be dashed as President Joe Biden downplayed the prospect of a one-on-one agreement between both countries.As the pair met at the White House, Mr Biden told reporters: Weaposre going to talk about trade a little bit today and weaposre gonna have to work that through.” He also failed to reject the assertion from his predecessor Barack Obamaaposs that Britain would be at the back of the queue for a deal. Mr Johnson had previously insisted the UK would be first in line for a free trade deal - which was touted by some Brexiteers as one of the major benefits of leaving the EU.  But attempts to kickstart trade talks on his first trip to the US since becoming PM appeared to fizzle out. Government insiders suggested Britain would look at other options including asking to join the the existing US-Mexico-Canada agreementinstead. A diplomatic source said: There are a iety of dferent ways to do this. The question is whether the US administration is ready. The ball is in the USaposs court. It takes two to tango. But a spokesman for the PM dismissed the comments on Wednesday in a briefing for Westminster reporters. Thataposs not an approach we are currently taking, the spokesman said.Our focus is on trying to negotiate a bilateral deal with the US, which is in the interests of Britain.Ex-President Donald Trump, who oversaw the USMCA pact, was more enthusiastic over the prospect of a free trade deal with Britain which he said would be fantastic and big.But the PM has sought to dampen expectations of an imminent agreement with Mr Biden. Environment Secretary George Eustice struck a downbeat note over the hopes of an UK-UK trade deal. He said that the UK still very much hope to be able to put together an agreement with the United States but itaposs just not a priority for the Biden administration.Mr Eustice also risked a row with the US when he said Mr Biden was wrong over Brexit.The President, who is proud of his Irish roots, had raised concerns about the impact of part of Mr Johnsonaposs EU trade deal on peace on the island of Ireland.  The Northern Ireland protocol, a key part of the deal, has created a trade border in the Irish Sea by effectively keeping it in the EUaposs single market for goods. During his White House summit with the PM, Mr Biden said he felt very strongly about any issues to the peace process. And I would not at all like to see - nor, I might add, would many of my Republican colleagues like to see - a change in the Irish accords, the end result having a closed border in Ireland, he said. Mr Johnson said thataposs absolutely right, adding: On that point, Joe, weaposre completely at one, nobody wants to see anything that interrupts or unbalances the Belfast Good Friday Agreement. But back in the UK, Mr Eustice said the President is probably at the moment just reading the headlines. He told Sky News: We think he is wrong because the truth is that unless we have a sustainable solution that enables trade to continue between GB and Northern Ireland then we are going to have issues, and that itself would become a challenge to the Belfast Agreement. We will obviously explain to the United States effectively it is tantamount to saying that potatoes grown in one part of the United States canapost be sold in another part of the United States. When you explain some of those provisions in detail, it is understood by the US government that that clearly does not make any sense and therefore should be revisited. Mr Eustice said the protocol was very complicated and Iaposm not sure hedoes fully appreciate all of that. news politics universal-credit-top-tory-links-"Universal Credit: George Eustice discusses cutsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA top Cabinet Minister has claimed he is “comfortable” with hitting six million poor Brits with a £-a-week cut - despite the energy price crisis.Environment Secretary George Eustice, who is “a trustee of a family discretionary will trust which owns shares” in a -acre Cornish fruit and veg farm, backed stripping £, a year from households on Universal Credit.Asked by the BBChe felt “comfortable” with going ahead with the welfare cut, he admitted: “You have to look at all of these things in context and yes, the answer is I do. “Because we are seeing prices rise, yes, that is putting some pressure on household incomes. “But more importantly we are also seeing wages rise, particularly for the lowest paid. “It is a very tight labour market at the moment - there are over a million job vacancies at the moment, so those who want to work are finding it easy to find work.”  It comes despite more than million households on Universal Credit facing an energy bills hike of more than £ a year from October  - within weeks of the benefit being cut. Some .million of those households are estimated to be on the most expensive pre-payment meters and could end up paying £ more per year. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng was due to be grilled by MPs this morning over the soaring gas prices that are set to hammer family budgets at the same time as benefit cut. The Cabinet Minister appears before the Commons Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Select Committee amid mounting fears of blackouts and spiralling costs. Mr Kwarteng has ruled out nationalisation and is prepared to let dozens of smaller firms fail. But he has suggested taxpayer-backed loans could be offered to larger companies which take on customers of suppliers which go bust. Last night ministers handed over tens millions of pounds in taxpayersapos cash to resolve the carbon dioxideshortage that has hit food supplies. Industry figures had warned that shoppers could begin to see empty shelves within days due to a shortage of CO, which is used in the production process for meat and some frozen goods. The crisis was triggered when a major US-owned fertiliser firm - which produces CO as a by-product - halted UK production following a surge in wholesale gas prices. The Government has brokered a deal with CF Industries to restart production. Taxpayers will fund the firm’s operating costs for up to three weeks and the money won’t have to be repaid.  Environment Secretary George Eustice admitted there were still challenges in the food supply chain but insisted that Brits would not face shortages in the run up to the festive period. Despite the deal ending  weeks before Christmas he said today: “Christmas is safe, of course.” Universal Credit’s own architect, Baroness Philippa Stroud, has warned it will hit more than , people who are teetering on the poverty line. Yet Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey previously said she was “entirely happy” with slashing the benefit.Asked earlier this month are you entirely happy with this , Ms Coffey told Sky News: Yes. We made this decision earlier this year, the Chancellor announced it in the Budget.And thataposs why we’re building the update to the plan for jobs to make sure as we see the end of the furlough scheme, the support that’s happened there, as we see the end of the other support schemes... that we accelerate our plan for jobs.Comment MORE ON Conservative PartyCF Industries Inc.Universal Credit" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: virtually every unvaccinated child covid
story: :root Virtually every unvaccinated child will get Covid at some point, says Prof WhittyAll children aged  to -years-old are now being offered a single dose of the Pfizer jabChildren aged  to  are now being offered a dose of the Covid vaccine Image: Dinendra Haria LNPByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsVirtually all young people will get Covid- at some pointthey arenapost vaccinated, Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer has said. Professor Chris Whitty told MPs that young people between  and -years-old are currently driving Covid transmission, with infection rates highest in this age group. All children aged  to -years-old are now being offered a single dose of the Pfizer jab after the UKaposs Chief Medical Officers backed the move. The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationhad stopped short of recommending this on medical grounds alone, effectively handing the decision to the CMOs. At a hearing of the Education Committee, Prof Whitty explained that the UKaposs top medics decided to recommend mass vaccination of jabs for under-s partly to prevent disruption in schools.  Prof Whitty said the comparison was between a child being vaccinated against a near certainty that child will get Covid. He said fewer school days would be lost due to being vaccinated compared to children getting the virus, as pupils with Covid would be off school - and some will have signicant symptoms. Asked about modelling for days lost due to short-term disruption by Tory chairman Robert Halfon, Prof Whitty said: “Our view is firmly that people who have an infection are likely to be off school for longer than people who have a vaccine, on average. “Therefore since virtually any child, unvaccinated, is likely to get an infection at some point between  and , that is the correct comparison, not against nothing. Children currently have the highest transmission rates of any age group, he said. Prof Whitty told MPs: There is definitely substantial transmission happening in this age group. In fact, the age group weaposre talking about is the one in which the highest rate of transmission is currently occurring, as far as we can tell.  But he said that vaccination will reduce that risk. Asked what how many youngsters have already had Covid, Prof Whitty said: It ies by age and it does also y by setting, but I thinkwe go for roughly half I think that is a reasonable stab at this. Thataposs half over the period of the entire epidemic to date, and weaposve got quite a way to run. Weaposre running into winter so thereaposs still quite a lot of damage that could be done in terms of disruption. Deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam told MPs that the Delta iant is so infectious it was not a theoretical risk. He said: I think it is really quite inevitable that they will be so at some point. Prof Van-Tam said it would be extremely inconvenient to be laid low with a cough, fever, and respiratory symptoms for pupils sitting GCSEs and A-Levels. Pupils in England began being offered their Covid vaccine in schools this week. The rollout is being managed by the School Age Immunisation Service , which already does inoculations for flu and HPV in schools. Parents are being asked to give consent for their children to be vaccinated. But children can overrule their parentsthey are deemed competent to make the decision through a legal precedent known as a Gillick competence. title: queen to meet great grandchild
story: :root Queen ‘to meet great-grandchild Lilibet for first time this Christmas’, says expertReports have suggested Prince Harry and Meghan are keen to visit the UK after moving to Calornia last year - Harry has only ed to the UK twice since the moveQueen Elizabeth II leaves Number  Downing Street after attending the Governments weekly Cabinet meeting in ByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe Queen is likely to meet her great-grandchild Lilibet for the first time this Christmas, a royal expert has suggested.After quitting as senior royals and moving to Calornia early last year, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are reportedly keen to visit the UK.Harry has only ed to the UK twice since the move, while Meghan and two-year-old Archie have not been back so far. A Christmasby the Sussexes would be a chance to work towards healing the rt in the Royal Family, according to royal author Katie Nicholl and author of Harry And Meghan: Le, Loss, And Love.Katie toldCloser magazine: When Harry and Meghan left, they made it clear they didn’t want to give up their home in Britain. They still have Frogmore Cottage and their plan was to come back to the UK.Christmas is being looked at as an opportunity. There may be a softening, which could pave the way for a healing of the family rt. ”It’s certainly what the Queen wants. Prince Charles would like to see his grandchildren. A meet-up suggests they hope to move on and sort things out. Harry and Meghanaposs newborn daughter Lilibet has not been to the UK since her birth in June and has yet to meet her great-grandmother or her grandfather Prince Charles. The last time the couple spent Christmas in the UK was in , seven months after their wedding. The pair have made few appearances since the birth of their most recent child but it has been reported that they are set to enter a “new era of visibility”. This weekend they are due to join a team of celebrities for a -hour global TV show in New York City, which organisers say is intended to “continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the COVID- pandemic for everyone, everywhere.  The trip to New York comes after they were also named in TIME magazineaposs  most influential people in . The magazine praised the pair for having compassion for the people they donapost know, adding: They donapost just opine. They run towards the struggle.” Their inclusion on the list was marked with a series of striking photos of the pair shot at their £million mansion in Calornia. title: boa constrictor found coughing up
story: :root Boa constrictor found coughing up blood amid fears village used as snake dumping groundResidents living in a Shropshire hamlet were left spooked after warnings the area could be being used as a place to abandon exotic petsThe six-foot snake was found abandoned in the roadByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsResidents of a quiet Shropshire hamlet were left horried after a six-foot-long boa constrictor was seen crawling along a country lane. The snake was bleeding from its jaw and seen coughing up blood opposite a layby on the B near Roden on Friday. RSPCA were called to attend the scene after the constrictor was discovered with a broken jaw by two motorists. Officers were able to safely contain the reptile in a large duvet cover using a specialist pole with a hook. The snake was taken to a vets and given pain relief but died later that night. The body of another long-deceased snake of a similar size was then found nearby, prompting fears that the road is being used as a place to dump unwanted exotic pets. Following an investigation, the local RSPCA said it believed both reptiles were deliberately abandoned in the area.  A spokesperson for the organisation said: “Normally when we get a call like this we find the snake has been misidentied and itaposs actually a small native species, so we were very surprised when we arrived and saw a six-foot boa constrictor on the road. ”Itaposs very sad that this beautul creatureaposs le ended like this. Sadly we think this snake was probably abandoned as itaposs a very isolated location and there are no houses around for at least a mile. The discovery of the body of another snake close by also leads us to believe that someone has deliberately left them.” Locals have described the findings as the “stuff of nightmares” and expressed fears for the safety of the neighbourhood and their children and pets. One person wrote on social media: Is it just me or is this freaking anybody  out  I donapost want live ft snakes slithering around the village.” Another added: This is literally the stuff of my nightmares. My skin is crawling just thinking about it.” A third person added: “You’ve got to think about these poor reptiles too, they won’t last long in our weather without the proper care.”In response, someone wrote: “Exactly, they will be hungry. And that’s why I don’t want to let my pet out. These animals can be brutal killers and would target something small.” Although non-venomous, boa constrictors are said to “eat almost anything” they can catch in the wild and their jaws can stretch wide enough to swallow large prey whole.  The RSPCA inspector said these sorts of incidents were “not unusual”, adding: “We receive hundreds of calls every year relating to reptiles, and some of these have either escaped or may have been abandoned by their owners. “Sadly snakes and lizards often end up in our care as some owners don’t realise the commitment that is involved in meeting their needs. title: boy 11 walk two miles
story: :root Boy walked two miles on busy roads to school after bus driver refused Scottish moneyKelly Mercer, , says son Ashton was left in tears after the driver of the Arriva bus in North Wales refused his £ Scottish note and he had to walk alone to school on a dangerous stretch of roadAshton, , was told his cash payment would not be accepted, his mum claimed Image: North Wales LiveByAaron LennoxTim Hanlon:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAn -year-old boy was left crying at a bus stop and forced to walk two miles to school on a dangerous stretch of road because the driver wouldnapost accept his cash payment, claimed his mum.Kelly Mercer, , says son Ashton was refused a ride on the Arriva bus that would have taken him direct to the school gates of Ysgol Aberconwy and instead had to cross busy roads on his walk, reported NorthWalesLive.The schoolboy would normally pay the fare using the Arriva App, but earlier that morning was having issues with it meaning he had no option but to pay in cash. He attempted to pay for his fare on board using a £ Scottish sterling note and claims to have been told the note was not a legal tender. It left him with no option but to walk the two mile journey to school which involved crossing the Conwy bridge and busy roads from Llandudno Junction.Speaking to North Wales Live, Kelly said: “I noticed The Arriva app wasn’t working earlier that morning when I tried buying Ashtonaposs bus ticket for him to get to school. “I gave him a five pound note, to get afor the day in hope that the app would work the following day so he could get his ‘M-Ticket’. “Unfortunately it happened to be a Scottish sterling note - which, regardless is a legal tender. “Ashton was waiting with friends on Victoria Drive for the bus and when it came the driver refused the payment, and told him the payment wasn’t a valid form of payment and refused to accept the note and making him exit the bus before it left. “He was left alone at one of Llandudno Junctions’ busiest points at half eight in the rush hour morning whilst the bus drove off with his friends on. “Having only been at the school two weeks, and turning  only six months ago, Ashton was left to walk to school which is just over two- miles from the bus stop in the freezing cold crying his eyes out that early in the morning. “He recently had stitches in his eyebrow from a head injury, and the stitches are noticeable, yet that driver still refused him, anything could have happened on that route to school.” She says she has contacted Arriva about what happened, but claims sheaposs had no apology, only a comment confirming that no child should be left alone at the side of the street. She added: Iaposm thankful that Ashton was so nervous about starting the school as this allowed me to drive the route with him several times before the term started, little did I know that would come into play for such silly reasons. ”You hand over your child to them. You expect that your child will be able to get to school safely. As a grown man, making a child walk two miles to school, that driver should feel ashamed of himself.” Arrivaaposs website states: Children aged under  and those people who, in the reasonable opinion of the driver, are vulnerable, at risk or in distress, and are unable to pay their fare will be carried at all times. They may be asked to provide their name and address in order that the fare due could be collected at a later date. In these circumstances, the driver will issue a single ticket for one journey allowing the inidual to travel to their home or the nearest stop thereto. Arriva have been contacted byfor comment. title: brave woman who volunteered covid
story: :root Brave woman who volunteered in Covid trial now trapped by unapproved vaccineLiz King from Abergavenny stepped forward to trial the Novavax vaccine last year saying she felt guilty as a retired nurse about not being there to help her colleagues during the first wave of the pandemicLiz King from Abergavenny stepped forward to trial the Novavax vaccine last year Image: Liz KingByWill Hayward:,  Sep | commentsA woman who bravely volunteered in a Covid trial says she now feels apostrappedapos after being given a still-unapproved vaccine - without hope of receiving another. Liz King from Abergavenny, south Wales, stepped forward to trial the Novavax vaccine last year saying she felt guilty as a retired nurse about not being there to help her colleagues during the first wave of the pandemicLiz was originally told thatany other approved vaccines came on the market she would be able to drop out of the study to take it up, reports Wales Online. She said: “I’m a retired nurse and felt incredibly guilty in the Spring of  that I wasn’t able to help my ex colleagues during the first wave of Covid-. So when I had the chance to volunteer for a vaccine trial I went for it.” “This was November before any vaccines were approved,” she said. “The saidan approved vaccine came on the market we could drop out of a trial, that was in the consent form but I also asked it verbally at my first appointment. “It was a blind trial and % of the participants had Novavax and % had saline [a placebo]. I thought I had had saline because I had no side effects at all, not even a sore arm. I had the first one in November and the second at the beginning of December.”  There Liz was asked to sign an updated consent for which was  pages long. She scanned through it and signed. Upon closer reading she realised that there was a small but signicant change. She said: “It said we would be discouraged from having an approved vaccine because using it with Pfizer or AstraZeneca hadn’t yet been tested. I wasnapost worried about it because we were being assured that because the vaccine had done well in phase one and phase two trials and that approval was imminent - in a couple of months at least. I was offered both Pfizer in January and AstraZeneca in April but I was happy to stay on the trial because I had been told by this point I knew I had had the vaccine not the placebo and it appeared it would be approved.” Fast forward to now and it seems likely thatthe Novavax vaccine is approved it won’t be until . Liz has tried to get another vaccine such as Pfizer but is now not allowed.  “I had been emailing the health board for a month trying to get a response and they never came back to me,” she said. “Then I rang and I was told they would call me back and they never called me back. So on Saturday I went to the walk-in centre in Newport and after waiting an hour while they had several discussions they eventually said no because I had been given the trial vaccine - when they said no I just burst into tears.” Liz is able to get a Covid pass because the NHS app acknowledges that she has had a vaccine. But because the vaccine is not approved she is facing the following problems: She cannot travel abroad anywhere which requires a vaccine. She has no ideathe vaccine she took actually offers her full protection because the final results are not out. Evenshe is protected she doesn’t knowthis immunity will wane. She is unable to get any booster jabs. “I am trapped,” she said. “It really is like something from Kafka. It is exactly what it is like. Itaposs not just me. There were , of us all across the UK but now some of them have jumped ship. I think some of them lied to get a dferent vaccine. Good on them, I wish I had. I donapost know how many of us are left but there must be thousands of us in this situation.” One of the frustrating things about this is that Liz took a risk to help develop the vaccines, but now is being affected to her detriment for doing so. She even volunteered at a vaccination centre this year. “Iaposve administered lots of other peopleaposs vaccines,” she said. “At the end of clinics sometimes we would have three or four doses left and we would be scrambling around to try and use up the remaining doses. I never once asked for one because I was committed to the trial I was doing.  “Now we are just stuck in this limbo. Last year they were all happy for us to take a jab and happy for us to do it. But now the nanny state is making decisions for me about whether or not Iaposm allowed a booster. “Iaposm not speaking out for me, Iaposm doing it for all of us who were on that trial. I want to have to approve vaccines and I want to be in the same position as the rest of the population. “I donapost want thanks butpeople like me hadn’t volunteered we wouldnapost have vaccines. At the very least I shouldnapost be inconvenienced after having volunteered. “I feel abandoned and so let down by the system. It is grossly unfair that people who volunteered to trial an experimental vaccine are at a disadvantage and have less rights and liberties than the general population. I will never volunteer again and will advise others not to.” Liz is very keen to point out that she has no problem with the Novavax vaccine itself and doesn’t want to do anything to suggest it isn’t effective. “I absolutely donapost want to cast any doubt on the Novavax vaccine,” she said. “The science will tell us how good it is or not and I donapost want to give any ammunition to anti-vaxxers. Iaposm not criticizing the vaccine in anyway - itaposs kept me safe for -  months.” A Health and Care Research Wales spokeswoman said: We really appreciate the hard work and involvement of all participants in Covid- vaccine clinical trials. Anyone participating in the Novavax trial should have had two active doses of vaccine and have protection against Covid-. We are aware of the issue affecting some participants having additional vaccinations and are awaiting the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationto advise further on this.” Comment MORE ON Newport CorporationAstraZeneca plcPfizer Inc.NHSNovavax Inc.Apps" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: brits face christmas without tree
story: :root Brits face Christmas without a tree as delivery chaos will cause shortagesPeople are being urged to book their festive trees in advance this year due to an expected shortage caused partly by a lack of lorry drivers and a surge in demandA shortage of lorry drivers and a surge in demand are part of the reason for a possible shortage Image: Getty ImagesByTim Hanlon:,  Sep | commentsBrits are being advised to book ahead for their Christmas trees this year due to expected shortages coupled with a likely surge in demand. A lack of lorry drivers and Covid restrictions mean that the usual deliveries of the festive trees could be affected said Chris Bonnett, the founder of Gardening Express. He’s also expecting a surge in demand after last yearaposs muted celebrations, as families and friends celebrate the festivities together. Lorry driver shortages in Denmark are expected to impact imports to the UK with any Covid related restrictions further adding to the problems. Denmark is a major producer of live Christmas trees with around % of its crop exported to other European nations. Last year it faced problems after it halted exports in an attempt to control a Coronavirus mutation found on mink farms.Now the shortage of drivers in Denmark could affect the distribution of Christmas trees across Europe. With fewer than  days until Christmas, Bonnett is already seeing a jump in the number of customers searching for Christmas trees on his site despite the festive range not yet fully live. He’s urging customers to order early to ensure they’re able to secure a tree ahead of the big day. It comes as the public have also been warned to prepare for a shortage of turkeys due to a lack of available CO, while there could also be empty shelves in supermarkets due to other delivery problems. Chris said: “The last few years have played havoc with the Christmas tree market. Mild winters in Scandinavian countries have made it more complicated to fell trees. Add in the Covid restrictions in place last year and the current shortage of lorry drivers and you can see why we’re concerned that there could be a shortage of trees. “A Christmas tree is an essential part of the festivities, not just on Christmas Day but in the run up - picking the tree, squeezing it into the car and decorating ahead of the celebrations. “This year it’ll mean even more after the locked down restrictions of last year which is why we’re already seeing a surge in the number of customers searching for Christmas trees. “Hopefully between now and December, things will improve.” Bonnett added: “We are seeing issues with disruption across the retail sector, from food and drink to gts and clothing. “For Britons really wanting to go all out to celebrate this year, the best advice is to plan ahead and get all the essentials pre-ordered so you can enjoy the festivities without the stress.”Comment MORE ON ChristmasChristmas treesCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: brits film themselves taking covid
story: :root Brits may have to film themselves taking Covid tests before jetting off on holidayTransport Secretary Grant Shapps has said he new testing rules which allow people to take lateral flow tests rather than more costly PCRs will come into force "as quickly as possible"Travellers may have to do tests on camera, it has been reported Image: Getty ImagesByMilo BoydReporter:,  Sep | commentsBritish holidaymakers may soon have to film themselves taking Covid tests before being allowed back into the UK. Under government plans unveiled last week, PCR swab tests are set to be replaced with lateral flows. While faster and cheaper, the tests do not need to be sent off to a lab for the results to come through, meaning they are open to fraud. Travel industry sources have said travellers might have to carry out a swab in sea or air terminals with officials watching to remove the chance of people cheating, thereports. Alternatively, they could be done via a video consultation.  A source told the publication: “You could have a simple mail-order system but the problem is that you have no verication whatsoever. “You only have to look at social media to see videos of people faking it.” It comes after Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said yesterday the Government aimed to introduce the new testing regime for fully jabbed travellers “as quickly as possible”.  If the new regime comes into force before October half term, holidays will be signicantly cheaper for those looking to get away. Typically lateral flow tests cost a lot less than PCRs, which have added hundreds of pounds to holiday bills. Mr Shapps told the Transport Committee hearing on Wednesday that he did not have an exact date for when testing restrictions would be lted but said his colleagues at the Department of Health are aware of half term when families will be wishing to go on holiday. Itaposs clear the range of measures I introduced this week and last week are going to make a big dference and people will be able to travel much more freely, he said. Part of that is the removal of the PCR test on day two and replacing it with a much simpler lateral flow test. Theyare aware of half term and are working closely with the private-sector providers to ensure we can do this as quickly as possible. The Department for Health, which is in charge of testing, has been contacted for comment. title: builder says hes solved housing
story: :root Builder says hes solved the housing crisis with tiny two-bed home on wheelsChris Metcalf, from Falmouth, has built a two-bedroom transportable house that has all the same necessities as a regular property. It is made of metal and wood and is on sale for £,The house on wheels is up for sale for £, and is stylishly decorated throughout Image: DeeGee PHOTO   SWNSByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep | commentsA home builder believes his pint-sized property built on wheels and on sale for £K is the solution to the housing crisis. The unusual property is made of metal and wood and has everything a normal house would, but with one main dference - it is built on a trailer. The tiny Cornish house makes for a great holiday home as it can be attached to a car and driven around. The property, which is on sale in Falmouth, consists of a fully installed navy kitchen and stylish grey bathroom. It also has two bedrooms, making it perfect for a family, and a living room - as well as electricity and plumbing throughout. Chris Metcalf, the brains behind the property, believes homes such as this could be the key to ending the housing crisis. In Britain, a record amount of people are unable to buy a property, butmore homes such as this one were built, that could maybe change. The homeaposs advert reads: The Tiny House On Wheels is a locally made, unique and innovative housing solution.  Built on top of a purpose built steel chassis for ease of transporting to its forever home, the Tiny House is ideal for additional guest accommodation, a den for teenagers, or even a work from home study! Popular with buyers looking for an additional Air B  B type income, the Tiny House On Wheels can be parked on private landand mains Electrics and water hook up capability. The Tiny House has everything you need for comfortable day to day living, with a fully fitted kitchen and bathroom, a double bedroom and a single bedroom. The Tiny House is both stylish and finished to a high specication and is to be sold complete with fixtures and fittings. The property is being marketed by Martin  Co. and is on sale for £,. Mr Metcalf, an Electrician, spent more than a year building the home - which is advertised on Rightmove. He said: apos“ think it’s a really cool idea. title: bus shelter made giants baffles
story: :root Bus shelter made for giants baffles villagers with seats  inches off the groundA new bus shelter built in Fleering, Essex has been made too high, meaning villagers cannot reach the floor when they sit down. Commuters in the area have joked it has been made for giantsA local councillor is concerned that the bus shelter may mean that those with injuries will not be able to use it Image: James Linsell-Clark  SWNSByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep A bus stop has left villagers baffled as its seats are  inches too high - meaning no one can touch the floor when sitting. Residents joke the bus stop in Fleering, Essex, which has been newly installed, was made for giants. Local Councillor Paul Thorogood has said that his legs dangle when he sits on the seat- and he is ft tall. The height of the seats isn’t very user-friendly...unless you’re a giant! he complained. Iaposm ft and my legs are hanging off the edge. For a ft ins tall pensioner with a dodgy knee or hip it’s totally unusable. The bus shelter seats are meant to be  inches high. But one is  inches and the other is  inches.  Theyaposre brand new and should be fitted at the correct height. Cllr Thorogood said the developer that paid for the new bus stops, Bloor Homes, did so as part of a deal whereby they would erect  new homes in the area. However, it is Essex County Council and not Bloor Homes that must pay for any upkeep, leaving the tax payer to foot the bill for the replacement.  It is hoped that the developer will fix the bus shelter. Cllr Thorogood said: Somethingaposs not quite right. They havenapost fixed it yet but it will be in the pipeline hopefully. “Many people who are elderly or have a disability need to be able to sit down when waiting for a bus. “At the moment, they can’t.” Bloor Homes and Essex County Council were contacted for comment. title: can travel between uk latest
story: :root Can I travel to the US from UK  Latest rule changes explained with plans to lt banOn Monday, September , the US government confirmed that it will lt most restrictions on UK travellers, allowing them to enter the country for the first time since March Fully vaccinated travellers from the US and EU will be allowed to enter England without having to quarantine Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Sep | comments As of July , those who have been fully vaccinated in the UK donapost need to quarantine when theyfrom amber list countries.But despite being on the amber list, a travel ban is in place stopping Brits from travelling to the United States for a holiday. However, this is about to change. A travel ban has been in place for the UK and Ireland since March , but there are some exceptions to this rule.Recently, a change reignited hope that travel between the US and UK might be possible soon. Ministers confirmed that fully vaccinated travellers from the US and EU will be allowed to enter England without having to quarantine.And even more recently, the White House issued even further good news for UK travellers.  But what does this mean for the UK US travel ban  Here we explain the rules. Can I travel to the US  Currently, under US travel rules, only US citizens, and those who are permanent residents in the US, as well as close family members and other limited visa holders, can enter the US from the UK. In order to travel to the US, you have to meet the requirements for exemption. They state you need to be:an American citizen a permanent resident of the US a specied close family member of the above in a limited category of visa holderHowever, this will change from November when UK passengers who are double vaccinated can enter the country. The White House finally confirmed the news on September .The travel ban between the UK and UK has been in effect for since March .Then-president Donald Trump signed a presidential proclamation that can only be rescinded by the hitting president. Passengers flying into the US from anywhere  in the world need to show proof of a negative coronavirus test. The Centers for Disease Control and Preventionalso requires unvaccinated travellers to quarantine for at least seven days after arrival. They will also have to take a Covid test on days three and five. Only those who have been vaccinated with an FDA-authorised vaccine do not have to quarantine. Can people from the US travel to the UK   As of am on Monday August , those who have been fully vaccinated in the EU or US will not need to self isolate when coming to England from an Amber country. They do still need to have a negative Covid- test at least  hours before travel, and book a PCR test to be taken on or before day two when theyto the UK.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The travel advice currently urges people not to travel, but thatyou must travel to the United Kingdom, make sure you are fully vaccinated before travel.  Currently, the USA is on the UKaposs amber lists. This means that youaposll need to take a pre-departure test before heading to the UK, and then a PCR test on day two. Adults who are not fully vaccinated will also need to self-isolate for  days and take a second PCR test on day eight. title: couple 24 year age gap
story: :root Couple with -year age gap slam cruel strangers who branded husband a paedoBill and Lauren Kenn, from Kirkcaldy, Fe, Scotland, said strangers gawp at them when they hold hands in the street and Bill has been accused of liking children due to their relationshipLauren and Bill Kenn have refused to let the cruel comments bother them Image: HotSpot MediaByCandice FernandezMatthew DreschReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA woman whose husband is  years her senior has revealed how strangers cruelly labelled him a paedo. Lauren, , and Bill Kenn, , from Kirkcaldy, Fe, in Scotland, have been together for eight years, but still endure cruel taunts whenever they go out. Despite the couple getting together when Lauren was , Bill was targeted online by close friends who called him Jimmy Savile, while strangers have accused him of liking children. But the couple have refused to let the comments affect them and insist theyaposre happier than ever. Lauren, a stay-at-home mum, says: Since Bill and I got together, we have dealt with a lot of judgement. But we have learned to laugh it off and it has only made us stronger.  Bill is the love of my le and I know weaposre made for each other. In September , Lauren met Bill, a retired crane operator, at a local karaoke night. Lauren says: Bill was wriggling his hips and dancing before he came over to introduce himself. I was only  and I guessed he was around . Even though he was much older, I realised we both loved music, fancy dress and singing. We were so similar. Over the next few years, Lauren and Bill kept bumping into each other on nights out. Lauren says: I was living with my boyfriend at the time but I was really unhappy. Soon I began confiding in Bill and he was there for me. After a while, I finally ended my relationship. I needed a place to stay and Bill kindly offered.  The morning after I moved in, he told me heaposd fallen for me and kissed me. I wasnapost sure at first because of our age gap but as I got to know him more each day, my feelings grew. Weeks later, in February , Lauren and Bill became a couple. Lauren says: One month later, Bill was having a birthday party and it was then when realised I still didnapost know his age. He said he was turning . He was older than Iaposd originally thought. But I didnapost care. Shortly after, Lauren and Bill came clean about their relationship to their families. Lauren says: My parents were shocked at first.  My dad was especially wary and told me Bill was too old for me and that I could get any man I wanted. But thankfully when they met Bill a few weeks later, they loved him. After that, Bill told his five sons, from a previous marriage. As one of them was only two years younger than me, I was very nervous to meet them. But to my surprise, they welcomed me in with open arms. Despite Lauren and Bill having their familyaposs approval, they soon faced criticism from Billaposs friends. Lauren says: Bill and I went to the pub and one of his friends said aposPass the sick bucketapos and others laughed.  It was upsetting but Bill reassured me it was because they were jealous.Soon after, I got a Facebook message from a random woman saying that Bill had cheated on me with her.I broke down in tears and confronted Bill. Bill said it was all lies and it turned out the profile was fake. We realised it was one of Billaposs friends trying to split us up. It was so cruel. Weeks later, Lauren uploaded a photo of her and Bill on Facebook. Lauren says: One of his friends commented aposYou must be younger than all of his sons. Bill is like Jimmy Savile.apos I couldnapost believe sheaposd call Bill that. It was horrying. Bill and I cut her off for good.  But Lauren and Bill still receive comments from strangers. Lauren says: People around town constantly gawped at us whenever we held hands in public. Then one day, at the pub, a man called Bill a paedophile and said he must like kids. I snapped at him and said I was  and I was a grown adult. Thankfully the bouncer overheard and threw the man out. Another time a woman passed us on the street and said aposThat lady is with her grandad.apos Each time we had a mean comment, it only made Bill and I stronger. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The couple refused to let others ruin their relationship. In September , Bill proposed to Lauren while on holiday in Bulgaria. Six month later, in July , they tied the knot in front of their family and friends. Lauren says: Bill and I have been together for eight years now and we have a beautul baby girl, Emily-Rose, who is now one. Bill is constantly mistaken for Emily-Roseaposs grandad. But we laugh it off now. Bill is the best thing to ever happen to me and his age will never matter. title: couple decide against having kids
story: :root Couple decide against having kids so they can pamper dogs with £, of luxuriesClaire Kelly Johnston, from North Lanarkshire, Scotland, and husband Stewart feed their dogs Cupcake, Teddybear and Popcorn bacon and sausages and buy them £ worth of clothes every weekClaire Kelly and Stewart Johnston with their pets Image: @cupcake_teddybear_popcorn  CATEByCally Brooks:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA couple have decided against having children so they can afford to pamper their three pooches. Claire Kelly Johnston, , and Stewart Johnston, , have spent £, on their aposbabiesapos - Cupcake, three, Teddybear, two, and Popcorn, two - and have said they donapost plan on having any children now they have dogs. Pomeranians Teddybear and Cupcake and long-haired chihuahua Popcorn are treated to £ worth of clothes weekly alongside their gourmet diets, with Claire cooking them bacon and sausages at the weekend. The pupsapos routine consists of being dressed and groomed every morning, before being taken for walks in their prams and ing for a home cooked breakfast.  Claire, a bank manager, and her husband Stewart, a chef, say they no longer feel the need to have children after becoming aposparentsapos to their three adorable pooches. Claire, from North Lanarkshire, Scotland, said: We got Cupcake in September  and sheaposs the biggest a - I over-mothered her and because she was the first one, she was the most spoilt so now she rules the house. They all have so many clothes that Iaposve had to give them their own built in wardrobe!  I buy them new clothes every week because I canapost help myself - I always knew I would get outfits for them but didnapost expect to get them so many. Whatever you can get for kids, I try and get it for the dogs. Cupcake even has her own little pink toy Audi car and she loves sitting in there. If we hadnapost had dogs, we would have definitely had children.  When I got Cupcake, I felt like that was it I felt there was something missing and then when I got her, I knew thataposs what I wanted. Claire has over  outfits and , toys for her beloved pets and says they love living a le of luxury.  The pair organise their le around their pups and make sure they donapost miss out on holidays and trips out. Claire added: I treat my dogs like kids. When we go on holiday, we make sure we go on staycations so the dogs can come with us. If weaposre having a date night, theyaposll join us and eat whatever weaposre having like steak, chicken, or turkey.  We recently took them to a cafe and they turned their noses up at the bacon because it wasnapost smoked! They like their luxurious lestyle - they all sleep in our bed and love getting dressed up. I have no social le because when Iaposm not working, Iaposll take them to doggy friendly places. We have no plans of having kids because I treat my dogs like kids and love being a mum to them. Despite receiving a lot of backlash, Claire has no plans to get rid of their wardrobes and insists they love playing dress up. She added: When Iaposm working, Iaposll get home from work and put them in clothes straight away - they never go out naked. This morning, Cupcake ran into the dressing room and sat waiting for me to get her into her outfit because she loves being dressed up.  I get most of the clothes from an online boutique and theyaposre actually ambassadors for them now. I get negative comments all the time people think I shouldnapost dress them up but itaposs normal for us and the dogs love it. If the dogs are unhappy, Iaposd never do it but they love it and I get so much enjoyment out of it. They get a lot of attention on walks - I have a little bag, pram and buggy for them so we do get strange looks sometimes! The fluffy pooches have their own daily routine and are always tended to even when their parents are at work. Claire explained: We get up in the morning at am. They donapost like breakfast during the week but I cook them breakfast at the weekend. I clean their face, put their kibble out and Iaposll get them dressed. Iaposll ask them what they want to wear and when weaposre not working, weaposll take them to the beach or doggy friendly restaurants and cafes. They always sit at the table with us! I find it dficult leaving them when Iaposm working but we have a dog sitter that comes in and walks them throughout the day so theyaposre never alone for too long. title: couple save thousands diy wedding
story: :root Couple save thousands on DIY wedding with eBay dress and bouquet grown in gardenNewlyweds Alex and Dan Lilley searched eBay for the brides wedding dress and grew their own bouquets in the back garden - slashing an enormous £, from their wedding billA thrty newlywed couple, Alex and Dan Lilley from Harby, Nottinghamshire, knocked a massive £, off their wedding bill thanks to clever DIY hacks and buying Alexs dress on eBay Image: Maxine Grundy   SWNSByAmy ReastRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep | comments A thrty couple saved thousands on their wedding by buying a bridal dress on eBay and growing flower arrangements in their back garden.Newlyweds Alex and Dan Lilley created their dream wedding with  guests for just £, - thanks to nty tricks and hacks.The couple, from Harby in Nottinghamshire, utilised second-hand websites such as eBay and Facebook Marketplace to bring their dream wedding to le while keeping costs low.Thrty Alex, , even grew her own bouquet of flowers to walk down the aisle in front of their  guests. After getting engaged in , Alex, a store supervisor, and -year-old Dan, a factory maintenance manager, wanted to marry on a budget while saving for a house renovation. But the parents to Samuel, four, reckon their clever hacks saved them around £, - and it was the perfect day. Alex said: People can pay thousands and thousands for their dream wedding but we couldnapost justy it. Doing everything ourselves was ten times the amount of stress but the end result was amazing. We were nervous but the end result better than we ever could have imagined. We managed to keep budgets low and still have the perfect day - I wouldnapost have changed a thing. Alex and Dan had shelved their wedding preparation for two years due to the pandemic - before they decided to take the leap and set a date in March. In order to juggle a pricey home renovation on their three-bed detached bungalow alongside their wedding, they decided to take a thrty approach wherever possible. With the date set for August , it was all hands on deck for the couple alongside their friends and family to bring everything together in the ultimate DIY mission.  But despite the odds stacked against them with a -person guest list, the coupleaposs spending totted up to just over £, - miles below what many couples choose to spend on their big day. Alex said: We just couldnapost justy using the money on the wedding when we knew it was needed on our house. I searched online and saw a lot of people saying their weddings cost upwards of £,, and we werenapost going to spend that. But at the same time, we really wanted to get married, so we aimed to do both. The couple had their service at a local church - totalling £ - before everyone took a five minute stroll back to their house, where they hosted the reception in the back garden.  They cut costs on music by taking their own sound system and using a seven-day free trial on YouTube to stream it - and dodged paying for a verger as their friend at the church offered to step in for free. The outfits worn by the couple, their son, and their bridesmaids were second hand from sites - with Alex getting her own dress, a Kenneth Winston originally worth over £, for a steal of just £ on Facebook Marketplace. Alex added: I did have to pay an extra £ to have the dress altered by a seamstress - but it was still a great deal. The enormous marquees erected in their back garden were borrowed from friends for free, with £ spent on strands of lights to give it a cosy feel. Their giant three-tier cake was made by a dedicated family member for free, as a wedding gt - while green-fingered Alex grew her bouquet in their own back garden using packets of seeds totalling a just handful of pounds. Her home-grown bouquet was made of an arrangement of cosmos, lavender, eucalyptus, gypsophilia and achillea. Food on offer was a buffet spread to feed their  hungry guests - prepared by their loyal bridesmaids the day before - and featured Mediterranean-style dishes including baked salmon, antipasti kebabs and a bean salad. Shopping at Aldi, they got the whole lot for £ - around £ a head - along with bottles of own-brand Pimms and prosecco totalling £. By buying most of their decorations from stores such as The Range and Dunelm, they kitted out the entire aposdo with candles, chalkboards, bunting and hay bales for under £. Entertainment included hiring a local musician for £, a photo booth for £ and a childrenaposs bouncy castle for £. The total cost of the wedding came to around £, thanks to their thrty approach - instead of the tens of thousands many spend on their perfect day. Alex said: It was ten times the stress doing it yourself rather than paying someone , but the end result was better than we imagined. Weaposre lucky to have such supportive friends and family. The couple got the best of both worlds by celebrating their wedding while still renovating their house - and Alex revealed the thousands of pounds they saved have already gone to good use. She explained: Earlier in the year we knocked down a wall in our home and made a new dining room. We also had a new patio fitted and re-turfed the lawn. Just six weeks ahead of the wedding, we had a new driveway installed too. The newlywed parents set off on a week-long honeymoon in Cornwall with four-year-old Samuel before ing to married le to continue their renovation work. Reflecting on their journey, Alex said: It was partly me being stubborn and refusing to pay for something we could do ourselves - but it paid off! It does feel fabulous to have had that level of creativity. We wouldnapost have changed a thing! title: couple spend 7 months living
story: :root Couple spend  months living upstairs after house floods during lockdownMike Coles, who has lived in Woodwalton, Cambridgeshire, for  years, says he and we Christine were forced to live upstairs because it was not safe to move to a hotelMike Coles was unable to use the downstairs of his home for months Image: Cambridge NewsByAmy Jones:,  Sep | commentsA couple spent seven months having to live upstairs in their home after their home flooded. Mike Coles, who has lived in Woodwalton, Cambridgeshire, for  years, had been campaigning for  years after he first experienced flooding in the village.A decade later it flooded again in December , Cambridgeshire Live reports.This resulted in at least two properties suffering from flood damage, including the house where Mr Coles lives with his we Christine.The downstairs of their property was rendered unlivable and they were given the option to move to a hotel or to stay in their home upstairs. Unfortunately, the flooding happened during the height of the pandemic, and Mr Coles and his we did not feel comfortable staying in a hotel.Mr Coles said: “Instead, we just stayed upstairs for seven months. We managed, but it wasn’t the best situation, but we were safer here than we would be in a hotel.”  To push the campaigning further, Mike and Christine came up with the phrase the forgotten village” to help raise awareness of their situation and the need for something to be done. He said: “We stopped our house from being flooded once before,  years ago, that’s where the first campaign started because of the dyke.Mr Coles called and emailed the local authorities throughout the decade asking for help to reduce flooding in the area.Mr Coles said he would ask the authorities for the villageaposs gullies and dykes to be cleared to help prevent another flood from occurring. These dykes act as a type of barrier used to regulate and stop water from a river coming through, and a gully is a type of drain.  Explaining why his campaigning is important Mr Coles added: “I just think I owe this at least to my grandchildren. “I donapost want to leave this world feeling very sad and guilty about the fact that I didnapost do my best to help to leave a better place for my grandchildren than I lived it”. A Cambridgeshire County Council spokesperson said: “Three main risk areas have been identied: New Road, The Cross and village green, and Braefield. The council has undertaken visits to the affected areas and held meetings with residents, while our highways team has planned survey works to identy any obstructions within the watercourses. Gullies in Woodwalton are programmed to be cleansed between October and December . news uk-news emmys-snubbed-harry-meghans-oprah-"Meghan Markle: Experts on Oprah interview Emmy nominationByJenner Newton:,  Sep | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey missed out on an Emmy award because it was largely propaganda, a royal expert has claimed. The couple sat down for a tell-all chat with the talk show host in March and made several claims against the royal family. They alleged that there had been conversations about how dark son Archieaposs skin would be, and Meghan claimed she was denied help for her mental health despite having suicidal thoughts. The interview was nominated for a prestigious Emmy award in the Outstanding Hosted Nonfiction Series or Special category, but it was pipped to the post by the documentary Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy. Speaking to the Daily Star, royal expert and film critic Richard Fitzwilliams said he had originally thought it had a very good chance” of winning after it was screened in  countries and had Oprah fronting it.But he added: They were given too easy a le - there wasn’t a single point that Oprah pushed them on. You can see why an awards ceremony would see flaws that the average viewer would not pick up on. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .The fact that it did so well with the audience wouldn’t give it a right to win by itself. Following the airing of the chat earlier in the year, Buckingham Palace issued a statement saying the Queen was saddened by the allegations made by Harry and Meghan, but added that some recollections may y. However, in Finding Freedom, an unauthorised biography of the couple, friends of Harry and Meghan claim the Queen has not taken full ownership of the issues they raised during the Oprah interview.The authors of the updated book also say the statement did not go unnoticed.Meanwhile, Harry is set to appear on TV tonight in a BBC documentary that pays tribute to his late grandfather Prince Philip.The special programme, which also features the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Andrew and Prince Charles, was originally arranged to mark the Dukeaposs th birthday in June, but he sadly died two months before his centenary. Interviews with the royals were recorded both before and after Philipaposs death, with Harryaposs tributes filmed in Calornia where he now lives after quitting the UK. In one clip, Harry talks about his grandfather and grandmotheraposs relationship, calling them the most adorable couple. He says: The two of them together were just the most adorable couple. To me knowing the cheekiness of him and knowing that behind what the world sees you have two iniduals who were very much in love and both, from a very young age, have dedicated their le to service... that is an incredible bond between two people.
